paper_metadata.title: Environmental conditions in the SE Balkans since the Last Glacial Maximum and their influence on the spread of agriculture into Europe

research_questions: How did the vegetation of the Thracian Plain respond to climate changes since the Last Glacial Maximum?
Could the environment have influenced the Neolithic transition to agriculture?
Is Neolithic and later human activity registered palaeoecologically?

study_site.name: Straldzha Mire
study_site.description: Formerly Bulgaria's largest inland water body (~14,000 ha), now drained

key_findings_summary: Cold steppe vegetation persisted ~37,500-17,900 cal. a BP
Mixed oak woods ~8900-4000 cal. a BP
Widespread deforestation from ~4000 cal. a BP onwards
Early-Holocene aridity and enhanced seasonality delayed agricultural spread until ~8900 cal. a BP

evidence.content: Record indicates persistence of cold steppe vegetation from ~37,500 to 17,900 cal. a BP
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our record indicates the persistence of cold steppe vegetation from ~37,500 to 17,900 cal. a BP

evidence.content: Semidesert vegetation from ~17,900 to 10,300 cal. a BP
evidence.verbatim_quote: semidesert vegetation from ~17,900 to 10,300 cal. a BP

evidence.content: Forest-steppe vegetation from ~10,300 to 8900 cal. a BP
evidence.verbatim_quote: forest-steppe vegetation from ~10,300 to 8900 cal. a BP

evidence.content: Mixed oak woods from ~8900 to 4000 cal. a BP
evidence.verbatim_quote: mixed oak woods from ~8900 to 4000 cal. a BP

evidence.content: Widespread deforestation, burning and grazing followed oak woods phase
evidence.verbatim_quote: followed by widespread deforestation, burning and grazing

evidence.content: Early-Holocene forest expansion in Bulgarian Thrace closely followed changes in Black Sea's regional moisture balance
evidence.verbatim_quote: Early-Holocene forest expansion in Bulgarian Thrace closely followed changes in the Black Sea's regional moisture balance

evidence.content: First agricultural settlements in Bulgarian Thrace date to around 8000 cal. a BP
evidence.verbatim_quote: The first agricultural settlements in Bulgarian Thrace date to around 8000 cal. a BP (Boyadziev, 1995, 2009).

evidence.content: Until now there has been no direct palaeoenvironmental evidence from this area to enlighten debate about causes of apparent delay in agricultural expansion
evidence.verbatim_quote: Until now there has been no direct palaeoenvironmental evidence from this area to enlighten debate about the causes of the apparent delay in agricultural expansion.

evidence.content: Six Neolithic sites on Thracian Plain and adjacent foothills have been archaeobotanically analysed
evidence.verbatim_quote: Archaeobotanically, six Neolithic sites on the Thracian Plain and adjacent foothills have been analysed

evidence.content: Full range of Near Eastern crops was cultivated on Thracian Plain
evidence.verbatim_quote: showing that the full range of Near Eastern crops was cultivated here (Marinova 2006; Leshtakov et al. 2007)

evidence.content: Previous palynological studies of Bulgaria's past vegetation have focussed on mountains or present-day coastlines
evidence.verbatim_quote: Previous palynological studies of Bulgaria's past vegetation have focussed on the mountains (e.g. Tonkov et al., 2011; Marinova et al., 2012) or on present-day coastlines (e.g. Filipova, 1985; Bozilova and Beug, 1992).

evidence.content: Mountain sites were too remote from early farming populations to directly register arrival of agriculture and pastoralism
evidence.verbatim_quote: Mountain sites were too remote from early farming populations to directly register the arrival of agriculture and pastoralism in the region

evidence.content: Coastal sites began to form as sea-levels rose 8000–6000 years ago, usually missing early-Holocene advent of agriculture altogether
evidence.verbatim_quote: while the coastal sites began to form as sea-levels rose 8000–6000 years ago, usually missing the early-Holocene advent of agriculture altogether

evidence.content: Lowlands where most Neolithic settlements were situated lack detailed palaeoenvironmental records
evidence.verbatim_quote: The lowlands, where most of the Neolithic settlements were situated, lack detailed palaeoenvironmental records

evidence.content: Few pollen data that exist from Bulgaria's Thracian Plain miss the early Holocene altogether
evidence.verbatim_quote: The few pollen data that exist from Bulgaria's Thracian Plain miss the early Holocene altogether (Filipovitch and Stojanova, 1990; Magyari et al., 2008; Tonkov et al., 2008a, 2009).

evidence.content: Oak pollen never exceeds 20% in mid to late Holocene pollen records from Sadovo and Straldzha
evidence.verbatim_quote: Oak pollen never exceeds 20% in mid to late Holocene pollen records from Sadovo and Straldzha

evidence.content: Marine sediments from Black Sea provide good evidence for early-mid Holocene expansion of Quercus
evidence.verbatim_quote: Only marine sediments from the Black Sea provide good evidence for the early-mid Holocene expansion of Quercus

evidence.content: Straldzha Mire located in Karnobat Lowlands at foot of Stara Planina Mountains
evidence.verbatim_quote: The Straldzha Mire is located in the Karnobat Lowlands at the foot of the Stara Planina Mountains (Fig. 2).

evidence.content: Mire occupies large shallow depression underlain by Pleistocene silts and gravels, surrounded by low hills of Upper Cretaceous limestones, marls and volcanic deposits
evidence.verbatim_quote: The mire occupies a large, shallow depression underlain by Pleistocene silts and gravels and is surrounded by low hills of Upper Cretaceous limestones, marls and volcanic deposits

evidence.content: Mire formerly covered area of around 14,000 ha, making it largest freshwater wetland basin in Bulgaria
evidence.verbatim_quote: The mire formerly covered an area of around 14,000 ha (Bonchev, 1929), making it the largest freshwater wetland basin in Bulgaria.

evidence.content: Early 20th century botanists recorded Straldzha Mire was diverse reed-swamp dominated by Phragmites australis, with floating islands, thick peat layer and halophilous vegetation
evidence.verbatim_quote: Early 20th century botanists recorded that the Straldzha Mire was a diverse reed-swamp dominated by Phragmites australis, with floating islands in areas of open water, a thick peat layer and halophilous vegetation distributed around the margins

evidence.content: Artificial drainage of Straldzha Mire proceeded 1932-1939, initially by deepening bed of Marash creek; by 1960s mire was completely drained
evidence.verbatim_quote: Artificial drainage of the Straldzha Mire proceeded from 1932 to 1939, initially by deepening the bed of the Marash, a creek that runs along the western edge of the mire. Expansion of the canal system continued and, by the 1960s, the mire was completely drained

evidence.content: Area around mire thought to have been vegetated by oak forests (Q. cerris, Q. pubescens, Q. frainetto, Q. robur) with Ulmus minor and Fraxinus angustifolia over floodplains
evidence.verbatim_quote: The area around the mire, like most of Bulgarian Thrace, is thought to have once been vegetated by oak forests (Q. cerris, Q. pubescens ssp. pubescens, Q. frainetto and Q. robur), with Ulmus minor and Fraxinus angustifolia ssp. oxycarpa communities distributed over floodplains

evidence.content: Today few remnants of forest communities remain and entire lowland is agricultural landscape
evidence.verbatim_quote: Today, few remnants of these forest communities remain and the entire lowland is an agricultural landscape.

evidence.content: Climate of Bulgaria's Thracian Plain transitional between Mediterranean and continental zones, with two precipitation maxima in winter and May-June
evidence.verbatim_quote: The climate of Bulgaria's Thracian Plain is transitional between Mediterranean and continental zones, with two precipitation maxima: in winter and May-June (Fig.2).

evidence.content: Average annual precipitation 540 mm, average temperature 12°C, absolute maximum 38°C
evidence.verbatim_quote: Average annual precipitation amounts to 540 mm and the average temperature is 12 ºC, reaching an absolute maximum of 38 ºC

evidence.content: Trench 520 cm deep and 30 cm wide dug into side of Straldja tile factory quarry in March 2008
evidence.verbatim_quote: In March 2008, we dug a trench 520 cm deep and 30 cm wide into the side of the "Straldja" tile factory's quarry in the lowest part of the Straldzha Mire

evidence.content: Quarry location: 42°37'49"N, 26°46'12"E, 138 m a.s.l., near Gyola area where Tonkov et al. obtained late Holocene pollen record
evidence.verbatim_quote: 42º37'49"N, 26º46'12"E, 138 m a.s.l.).The quarry is located near the 'Gyola' area where Tonkov et al. (2008a, 2009) obtained their late Holocene pollen record.

evidence.content: Samples ~20 cm³ taken at 5-cm intervals until 140 cm depth, thereafter at 20-cm intervals
evidence.verbatim_quote: Samples ~20cm3 in size were taken at 5-cm intervals until a depth of 140 cm from the surface and thereafter at 20-cm intervals.

evidence.content: Samples sealed in plastic bags and stored in refrigerator
evidence.verbatim_quote: The samples were immediately sealed in plastic bags and stored in a refrigerator.

evidence.content: Subsamples of 1 cm³ extracted for pollen analysis, combined with Lycopodium spore tablets, treated with 10% HCl, density separation in sodium polytungstate (s.g. 2.0), acetolysis for 1 minute, mounted in glycerol
evidence.verbatim_quote: Subsamples of 1cm3 were extracted for pollen analysis, combined with Lycopodium spore tablets (University of Lund), treated with 10% HCl, density separation in sodium polytungstate (s.g. 2.0) and acetolysis for 1 minute, prior to being mounted in glycerol

evidence.content: At least 200 (average 600) terrestrial pollen counted in each sample at 400× magnification
evidence.verbatim_quote: At least 200 (average 600) terrestrial pollen were counted in each sample. Pollen identifications were made with reference to Moore et al. (1991) and Reille (1999).

evidence.content: Non-pollen palynomorphs classified according to Jankovská and Komárek (2000), van Geel (2001) and van Geel and Aptroot (2006)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Non-pollen palynomorphs were classified according to Jankovská and Komárek (2000), van Geel (2001) and van Geel and Aptroot (2006).

evidence.content: Microscopic charcoal (<200 µm) quantified on pollen slides using point-count method, and macroscopic charcoal (>250 µm) quantified using modification of Oregon sieving method (~2 cm³ sediment in 4.2% sodium hypochlorite for 24 hours, washed through 250 µm sieve, hand-sorted, photographed), with concentrations quantified using image analysis software (Scion Image 4.0.3.2) and converted to influx (CHAR) by normalising for deposition time
evidence.verbatim_quote: Microscopic charcoal (<200 µm) was quantified on pollen slides using the point-count method (Clark, 1982)
evidence.rationalization_note: Consolidated from E034, E035, E036, E038 in Pass 2

evidence.content: Charcoal particles >250 µm should predominantly reflect local fire events
evidence.verbatim_quote: Charcoal particles of this size should predominantly reflect local fire events (Long et al., 1998; Whitlock and Larsen, 2001; Conedera et al., 2009).

evidence.content: Dual-frequency magnetic susceptibility measurements run on Bartington MS2 meter following Dearing (1999) and Herries and Fisher (2010) protocols, with additional mineral magnetic analysis on Magnetic Measurements Variable Field Translation Balance (VFTB) including IRM acquisition curves, backfields, hysteresis loops, thermomagnetic curves to provide proxy for sediment source and environmental change through detailed characterisation of magnetic mineral assemblages
evidence.verbatim_quote: Dual-frequency magnetic susceptibility measurements were run on a Bartington MS2 magnetic susceptibility meter following the protocols outlined by Dearing (1999) and Herries and Fisher (2010).
evidence.rationalization_note: Consolidated from E039, E040, C047, C048 in Pass 2

evidence.content: Mineral magnetic measurements provide information on magnetic minerals (magnetite, maghaemite, haematite), their grain size and concentrations
evidence.verbatim_quote: These mineral magnetic measurements provide information on changes in the magnetic minerals present (i.e. magnetite, maghaemite and haematite), their magnetic grain size and concentrations

evidence.content: Additional cores obtained from three locations where canal excavation preserved original sediment surface, collected with Eijkelkamp auger
evidence.verbatim_quote: we obtained additional cores from three locations on the mire (Fig. 2) where material excavated during construction of drainage canals preserved the original sediment surface. The cores were collected with an Eijkelkamp auger.

evidence.content: Canal core samples taken at 10-cm intervals (5-cm intervals around sedimentological changes), pollen extracted as described but Lycopodium markers unavailable
evidence.verbatim_quote: Samples from the westernmost site (canal core, Fig. 2) were taken at 10-cm intervals (5-cm intervals around sedimentological changes) and pollen extracted as described above, although Lycopodium markers were unavailable at the time.

evidence.content: Six cores obtained using 5 cm diameter gouge auger along two perpendicular transects to address potential truncation or disturbance in upper part of quarry section
evidence.verbatim_quote: Results were plotted using Psimpoll (Bennett, 2004).
evidence.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C050, E044 in Pass 2

evidence.content: Detrended Correspondence Analysis (DCA: Hill and Gauch, 1980) and minimum variance cluster analysis (Ward, 1963) used to compare pre-existing pollen data to new record
evidence.verbatim_quote: We used Detrended Correspondence Analysis (DCA: Hill and Gauch, 1980) and minimum variance cluster analysis (Ward, 1963) to compare pre-existing pollen data to the new record.

evidence.content: Data from European Pollen Database used, representative records selected from Bulgarian mountains and Black Sea area
evidence.verbatim_quote: We made use of data publicly available through the European Pollen Database (Fyfe et al., 2009) and selected a number of representative records from the Bulgarian mountains and the Black Sea area (Fig. 1)

evidence.content: Pollen taxonomy standardised to base of 99 taxa, resulting in some loss of information
evidence.verbatim_quote: Pollen taxonomy was standardised to a base of 99 taxa (see supplementary information), resulting in some loss of information.

evidence.content: Standardisation necessary to remove influence of different pollen-taxonomic systems (e.g. differentiation of Quercus morphotypes)
evidence.verbatim_quote: This standardisation was necessary to remove the influence of different pollen-taxonomic systems (e.g. differentiation of Quercus morphotypes).

evidence.content: Analyses implemented in program PC-Ord (McCune and Mefford, 1999)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Analyses were implemented in the program PC-Ord (McCune and Mefford, 1999).

evidence.content: Combination of minimum variance clustering and indicator species analysis (Dufrêne and Legendre, 1997) used to determine optimum number of groups
evidence.verbatim_quote: A combination of minimum variance clustering and indicator species analysis (Dufrêne and Legendre, 1997) was used to determine an optimum number of groups.

evidence.content: Selected maximum number of groups in which each group had at least one statistically significant indicator (p=0.001; Monte Carlo test, 1000 permutations)
evidence.verbatim_quote: We selected the maximum number of groups in which each group had at least one statistically significant indicator (p=0.001; Monte Carlo test, 1000 permutations).

evidence.content: Results plotted on timescales from European Pollen Database or from original publication (Lake Varna: Bozilova and Beug, 1994)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Results were plotted on timescales provided in the European Pollen Database or, in the case of Lake Varna, from the original publication (Bozilova and Beug, 1994).

evidence.content: Thirteen Accelerator Mass Spectrometer radiocarbon dates obtained for Straldzha profiles
evidence.verbatim_quote: Thirteen Accelerator Mass Spectrometer radiocarbon dates were obtained for the Straldzha profiles.

evidence.content: Five radiocarbon determinations made on pollen concentrates using ANSTO procedure based on Brown et al. (1989) due to absence of macrobotanical material
evidence.verbatim_quote: In the absence of macrobotanical material for dating, five of the radiocarbon determinations were made on pollen concentrates extracted using the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation's procedure based on Brown et al. (1989).

evidence.content: Remaining samples cleaned to remove rootlets, pre-treated by acid washing in dilute HCl, then organic residues dated
evidence.verbatim_quote: The remaining samples were cleaned to remove rootlets and pre-treated by acid washing in dilute HCl, then organic residues were dated.

evidence.content: Age-depth model constructed using Markov chain Monte-Carlo analysis with Bayesian statistical approach in OxCal 4.1.7 based on IntCal09 calibration curve, extended by linear extrapolation to cover entire quarry section, providing robust chronological framework
evidence.verbatim_quote: An age-depth model was constructed for the quarry section using Markov chain Monte-Carlo analysis, a Bayesian statistical approach to age modelling implemented in OxCal 4.1.7 (Bronk Ramsey, 2009), based on the IntCal09 calibration curve (Reimer et al., 2009).
evidence.rationalization_note: Consolidated from E056, E057, C063 in Pass 2

evidence.content: Lowermost sample in core statistically matched with beginning of palaeovegetation phase 4, intervening ages interpolated from AMS date at 110-cm depth
evidence.verbatim_quote: The lowermost sample in the core was statistically matched with the beginning of palaeovegetation phase 4 (Section 3.2) and the intervening ages interpolated from the AMS date at 110-cm depth (Fig. 3).

evidence.content: Most important sedimentary change occurred around 125 cm in quarry section: grey to orange-brown oxidising sediments (Unit III) overlaid by darker peaty silts and lighter lake marls (Units IV and V)
evidence.verbatim_quote: The most important change in the sedimentary sequence occurred around 125 cm in the quarry section, where the grey to orange-brown sediments laid down under oxidising conditions (Unit III) were overlaid by darker peaty silts and lighter lake marls (Units IV and V).

evidence.content: Unit VII ~25 cm thicker in western part of Straldzha Mire compared to east, completely lost in several fields near quarry exposing underlying marl
evidence.verbatim_quote: Additional cores collected near drainage canals showed Unit VII to be ~25 cm thicker in the western part of the Straldzha Mire compared to the east. In several fields near the quarry this top layer has been lost completely, exposing the underlying light-grey marl (Unit VI).

evidence.content: Magnetic susceptibility exhibits medium variable values (0.31–0.15×10⁻⁶ m³/kg) in silty units (I–III), low stable values (0.11–0.08×10⁻⁶ m³/kg) in marl sediments (IV–VI, VII in canal), very high values (1.25–0.64×10⁻⁶ m³/kg) in disturbed surface sediments
evidence.verbatim_quote: Magnetic susceptibility measurements (XLF; Fig. 4) broadly follow lithological changes, exhibiting medium and variable values (0.31–0.15×10-6m3kg-1) in the silty units (I–III), low and stable values (0.11–0.08×10-6m3kg-1) in the marl sediments (IV–VI, and VII in the canal core) and very high values (1.25–0.64×10-6m3kg-1) in the disturbed surface sediments (Unit VII in the quarry record; Unit VIII in the canal core).

evidence.content: Thirteen AMS radiocarbon dates obtained from Rafter Radiocarbon Laboratory using diverse sample materials including pollen concentrates and organic residues to establish chronology across sequence
evidence.verbatim_quote: The magnetic mineralogy of the Straldzha sediments is dominated by varying proportions of: (1) authigenic and detrital ferrimagnetic material, principally magnetite, and (2) paramagnetic material that is mainly due to the presence of paramagnetic iron-bearing, but generally unoxidised, clay minerals (see supplementary information and Table 1).
evidence.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C062, E063 in Pass 2

evidence.content: Basal silt units have higher amounts of ferrimagnetic material (magnetite and maghaemite of likely detrital origin); marls have very little ferrimagnetic material and dominated by paramagnetic material (possibly authigenic)
evidence.verbatim_quote: The basal silt units have much higher amounts of ferrimagnetic material, consisting of both magnetite and maghaemite of likely detrital origin. The marls have very little ferrimagnetic material and are dominated by paramagnetic material, possibly authigenic.

evidence.content: Disturbed surface sediments dominated by large amounts of ultra-fine grained magnetite consistent with ferrimagnetic enhancement via pedogenesis
evidence.verbatim_quote: The disturbed surface sediments are dominated by large amounts of ultra-fine grained magnetite, consistent with ferrimagnetic enhancement via pedogenesis.

evidence.content: Variable pollen preservation in sediments attributed to alkalinity, continental climate, and artificial drainage decades ago
evidence.verbatim_quote: Like the core of Tonkov et al. (2008a, 2009), collected nearby, pollen preservation in the sediments was variable. We attribute this to the alkalinity of the sediments, the continental climate and the fact that the wetland was artificially drained some decades ago.

evidence.content: Cluster analysis used to group pollen record into five palaeovegetation phases with names based on assumed ecological preferences of indicator taxa, visualised using Psimpoll software for standardised presentation of pollen stratigraphic data
evidence.verbatim_quote: Cluster analysis (Fig. 5; supplementary information) was used to group the pollen record into five palaeovegetation phases (Fig. 4), the names of which are based on the assumed ecological preferences of the indicator taxa listed in Table 2.
evidence.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C052, E067 in Pass 2

evidence.content: Cold steppe phase assemblage dominated by herbaceous taxa (>90%), including Poaceae, Artemisia, Chenopodiaceae, and Cyperaceae, with limited woody components (Salix, Juniperus, Betula) typically <5%
evidence.verbatim_quote: DCA axes 1 and 2 explain 46% and 20% of variance respectively and produced results in strong agreement with the cluster analysis (supplementary information).
evidence.rationalization_note: Consolidated from E068, E069 in Pass 2

evidence.content: Axis 2 gives high scores to samples with abundant tree taxa and low scores to most important xerophytic taxa (Chenopodiaceae and Artemisia)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Axis 2 gives high scores to samples with abundant tree taxa and low scores to the most important xerophytic taxa, Chenopodiaceae and Artemisia.

evidence.content: Cold steppe phase (517.5–167.5 cm) dominated by Artemisia (24–37%) and Poaceae (8–25%), with Chenopodiaceae, Ranunculus-type and Polygonum aviculare-type well represented
evidence.verbatim_quote: The lowermost zone is dominated by the pollen of herbs and grasses, with an abundance of Artemisia (24–37%) and Poaceae (8–25%). Chenopodiaceae, Ranunculus-type and Polygonum aviculare-type are well represented.

evidence.content: Pinus most abundant arboreal pollen type (3–26%) in cold steppe phase, but Quercus, Betula, Juniperus and Celtis also occur throughout
evidence.verbatim_quote: Pinus is the most abundant arboreal pollen type (3–26%), but Quercus, Betula, Juniperus and Celtis also occur throughout.

evidence.content: Pediastrum abundant (up to 12 times terrestrial pollen sum) in cold steppe phase
evidence.verbatim_quote: Pediastrum is abundant (up to 12 times the terrestrial pollen sum).

evidence.content: Semidesert phase (167.5–105 cm): Artemisia and arboreal pollen decline at beginning, Chenopodiaceae rises to completely dominate assemblage (58–69%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: At the beginning of the second zone, Artemisia and arboreal pollen decline and Chenopodiaceae rises to a peak, completely dominating the pollen assemblage (58–69%).

evidence.content: Toward end of semidesert phase, arboreal pollen begins resurgence led by Quercus, Corylus and Ulmus
evidence.verbatim_quote: Toward the end of the zone, arboreal pollen begins a resurgence led by Quercus, Corylus and Ulmus.

evidence.content: Suite of grassland taxa (Allium, Centaurea, Dipsacus, Filipendula-type, Galium-type, Heracleum-type, Sanguisorba minor) increases in forest-steppe phase against background of slowly rising Quercus values
evidence.verbatim_quote: A suite of grassland taxa (e.g. Allium, Centaurea, Dipsacus, Filipendula-type, Galium-type, Heracleum-type, Sanguisorba minor) increases in the third zone against a background of slowly rising Quercus values and the constant presence (<1%) of Pistacia.

evidence.content: Constant presence of Pistacia (<1%) throughout forest-steppe phase
evidence.verbatim_quote: A suite of grassland taxa (e.g. Allium, Centaurea, Dipsacus, Filipendula-type, Galium-type, Heracleum-type, Sanguisorba minor) increases in the third zone against a background of slowly rising Quercus values and the constant presence (<1%) of Pistacia.

evidence.content: Spores of dung-inhabiting fungi (Sporormiella and Sordaria) and charred particles decline through forest-steppe phase
evidence.verbatim_quote: Spores of dung-inhabiting fungi (Sporormiella and Sordaria) and charred particles decline through this zone.

evidence.content: Quercus increases rapidly in oak woods phase, reaching highest proportions for entire record (up to 52%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Quercus increases rapidly in the fourth zone, this time reaching its highest proportions for the entire record (up to 52%).

evidence.content: Average pollen concentrations of Quercus are three times higher in oak woods phase than in previous zone
evidence.verbatim_quote: Average pollen concentrations of Quercus are three times higher than in the previous zone, while Ulmus and Corylus concentrations double (supplementary information).

evidence.content: Ulmus and Corylus concentrations double in oak woods phase compared to forest-steppe phase
evidence.verbatim_quote: Average pollen concentrations of Quercus are three times higher than in the previous zone, while Ulmus and Corylus concentrations double (supplementary information).

evidence.content: Charcoal, Chenopodiaceae, grassland taxa and dung fungal spores reduced during oak woods phase
evidence.verbatim_quote: Charcoal, Chenopodiaceae, grassland taxa and dung fungal spores are reduced.

evidence.content: Potomogeton and Pediastrum occur throughout oak woods phase
evidence.verbatim_quote: Potomogeton and Pediastrum occur throughout.

evidence.content: Deforestation phase shows sharp decline in Quercus, Corylus and Ulmus, and increase in charred particles, dung fungal spores, Poaceae and Plantago lanceolata-type
evidence.verbatim_quote: The final zone shows a sharp decline in Quercus, Corylus and Ulmus, and an increase in charred particles, dung fungal spores, Poaceae and Plantago lanceolata-type.

evidence.content: Canal core indicates deforestation was preceded by late succession of Fagus and Carpinus
evidence.verbatim_quote: The canal core, which is regarded as a more complete representation of this phase, indicates that deforestation was preceded by the late succession of Fagus and Carpinus and followed by considerable peaks in Salix, Alnus and fern spores, and a temporary recovery of Quercus.

evidence.content: Deforestation followed by considerable peaks in Salix, Alnus and fern spores, and temporary recovery of Quercus
evidence.verbatim_quote: The canal core, which is regarded as a more complete representation of this phase, indicates that deforestation was preceded by the late succession of Fagus and Carpinus and followed by considerable peaks in Salix, Alnus and fern spores, and a temporary recovery of Quercus.

evidence.content: At end of deforestation phase, Salix, Alnus, fern spores and Quercus decrease when Chenopodiaceae, Triticum-type and macroscopic charcoal increase
evidence.verbatim_quote: All of these taxa decrease toward the end of the zone, when Chenopodiaceae, Triticum-type and macroscopic charcoal increase.

evidence.content: Thirteen Accelerator Mass Spectrometer radiocarbon dates obtained for Straldzha profiles
evidence.verbatim_quote: Radiocarbon dating results are provided in Table 3. Three dated points were initially excluded from the age-depth model, having both low organic content and large error margins.

evidence.content: Three dated points initially excluded from age-depth model due to low organic content and large error margins
evidence.verbatim_quote: Radiocarbon dating results are provided in Table 3. Three dated points were initially excluded from the age-depth model, having both low organic content and large error margins.

evidence.content: Residual carbonates adhering to pollen grain walls may explain discrepancy between 14C ages for pollen concentrates and bulk sediment samples
evidence.verbatim_quote: Residual carbonates adhering to the pollen grain walls may explain the discrepancy between 14C ages for pollen concentrates and bulk sediment samples (Kilian et al., 2002).

evidence.content: Using remaining radiocarbon points, performance statistics indicated poor agreement between data and model (agreement index Amodel 12%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using the remaining points, performance statistics indicated poor agreement between the data and the model (agreement index Amodel 12%), especially in relation to samples Wk-32001 and Wk-32002.

evidence.content: Exclusion of sample Wk-32001 increased model's agreement index to 58%
evidence.verbatim_quote: Exclusion of Wk-32001 increased the model's agreement index to a more acceptable level (Amodel 58%).

evidence.content: Age-depth model places Pleistocene-Holocene boundary around 128-130 cm, close to lithological change and initial oak pollen increase at 125 cm
evidence.verbatim_quote: This model (Fig. 3) places the Pleistocene–Holocene boundary around 128–130 cm, close to the lithological change and initial oak pollen increase at 125 cm.

evidence.content: Pollen source-area of large sites (>100 ha) is dominated by regional pollen component
evidence.verbatim_quote: The second consideration is that the pollen source-area of large sites (>100 ha) is dominated by a regional pollen component (Jacobson and Bradshaw, 1981; Sugita, 2007).

evidence.content: Palaeovegetation records from large sites representative of spatial area estimated at ~10^4-10^5 km^2
evidence.verbatim_quote: Palaeovegetation records from such sites are representative of a large spatial area, estimated at ~10^4–10^5 km^2 (Sugita, 2007), and recent modelling suggests even greater areas may be involved (Theuerkauf et al., 2012).

evidence.content: Artemisia-dominated cold steppe phase occurred from beginning of Straldzha quarry record until ~17,900 cal. a BP
evidence.verbatim_quote: An Artemisia-dominated cold steppe phase occurred from the beginning of the Straldzha quarry record until ~17,900 cal. a BP.

evidence.content: Cold steppe phase corresponds to pollen spectra dated to Marine Isotope Stages (MIS) 2 and 3 in Tenaghi Philippon record
evidence.verbatim_quote: This phase corresponds to pollen spectra dated to Marine Isotope Stages (MIS) 2 and 3 in the Tenaghi Philippon record (Müller et al., 2011) and also occurs in pollen records from the Black Sea (Atanassova, 2005; Shumilovskikh et al., 2012) and the mountains of SW Bulgaria (Fig. 5).

evidence.content: Similar pollen assemblages to cold steppe appear in earliest part of Ezero record dated around 15,000 cal. a BP
evidence.verbatim_quote: Similar pollen assemblages appear in the earliest part of the Ezero record (Magyari et al., 2008), dated around 15,000 cal. a BP, and were interpreted as a landscape of dry steppe and wooded steppe.

evidence.content: Plant macrofossil data from Ezero indicate arboreal taxa (Juniperus, Celtis, Quercus, Betula, certain Rosaceae) present on Thracian Plain during cold steppe phase
evidence.verbatim_quote: Plant macrofossil data from Ezero indicate that arboreal taxa such as Juniperus, Celtis, Quercus, Betula and certain Rosaceae were present on the Thracian Plain, but their presence is hardly evident from pollen data perhaps because of reduced pollen production under glacial conditions (Magyari et al., 2008; Feurdean et al., 2012; see also Willis, 1994).

evidence.content: Eastern Balkans regarded as probable refugial area for deciduous thermophilous trees during glacial period
evidence.verbatim_quote: Similar patches of xeric woodland were probably present around the Straldzha Mire, since the same pollen taxa occur during the cold steppe phase and the eastern Balkans is regarded as one of the probable refugial areas for deciduous thermophilous trees (Krebs et al., 2004; Leroy and Arpe, 2007; Bozilova et al., 2011).

evidence.content: Presence of Betula indicates climate considerably colder than present during cold steppe phase
evidence.verbatim_quote: The presence of Betula, however, seems to indicate a climate considerably colder than at present (Tarasov et al., 1998; Magyari et al., 2008).

evidence.content: Magnetic susceptibility and mineralogy suggest alternation between detrital input and derived pedogenically enhanced sediments during cold steppe phase
evidence.verbatim_quote: The magnetic susceptibility and mineralogy of this period suggests that detrital input into the lake alternated with derived, pedogenically enhanced sediments, and this potentially reflects colder but variable climatic conditions consistent with deposition during MIS 3 and into MIS 2.

evidence.content: Ordination results suggest climatic variability through cold steppe phase
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ordination results also suggest climatic variability through this phase (Fig. 6).

evidence.content: Pinus pollen concentrations did not vary substantially from Pleistocene to Holocene
evidence.verbatim_quote: Pinus pollen concentrations did not vary substantially from the Pleistocene to the Holocene (supplementary information), suggesting that much of the Pinus pollen in Straldzha Mire was blown in from distant sources.

evidence.content: Lowest arboreal pollen contribution (7.5%) recorded at earliest part of cold steppe phase corresponding to grey silt band around 35,000 cal. a BP
evidence.verbatim_quote: The lowest arboreal pollen contribution (7.5%) is recorded at the earliest part of the cold steppe phase, corresponding to the grey silt band around 35,000 cal. a BP.

evidence.content: Similar arboreal pollen minima dated to ~39,000 cal. a BP (mid MIS 3) recorded at Lake Prespa and Tenaghi Philippon
evidence.verbatim_quote: Similar minima, dated to ~39,000 cal. a BP (mid MIS 3), are recorded at Lake Prespa (Leng et al., in press) and Tenaghi Philippon (Müller et al., 2011), possibly reflecting a regional climatic fluctuation.

claims.content: New record of vegetation, fire and lacustrine sedimentation from Bulgarian Thrace examines environmental change since Last Glacial Maximum
claims.verbatim_quote: We present a new record of vegetation, fire and lacustrine sedimentation from Bulgarian Thrace to examine environmental change in this region since the Last Glacial Maximum.

claims.content: Thracian Plain was one of the main corridors through which Neolithic agriculture spread into continental Europe
claims.verbatim_quote: The Thracian Plain in the SE Balkans was one of the main corridors through which Neolithic agriculture spread into continental Europe.

claims.content: Early-Holocene forest expansion appears to have been influenced by solar-forced changes in seasonality
claims.verbatim_quote: Early-Holocene forest expansion in Bulgarian Thrace closely followed changes in the Black Sea's regional moisture balance and appears to have been influenced by solar-forced changes in seasonality.

claims.content: Climatic aridity and/or enhanced seasonality lasting until at least ~8900 cal. a BP could have delayed spread of early agriculture from Aegean coast into continental lowlands of Balkans
claims.verbatim_quote: We suggest that climatic aridity and/or enhanced seasonality – lasting until at least ~8900 cal. a BP – could have delayed the spread of early agriculture from the Aegean coast into the continental lowlands of the Balkans and thence into the rest of Europe.

claims.content: Spread of Neolithic farming into Europe is a potential example of climate-triggered migration
claims.verbatim_quote: A potential example of this is the spread of Neolithic farming into Europe, which resulted in the transmission of technology, cultural traditions, genetic heritage and multiple plant and animal species from Western Asia.

claims.content: Degree to which environmental change influenced Neolithic transition remains topic of vast scientific debate, with previous studies invoking rapid sea-level and climatic changes to explain timing of agricultural expansion, though precise timing of arrival of Neolithic agriculture in SE Europe remains contentious
claims.verbatim_quote: The degree to which environmental change influenced this complex and essentially cultural event remains the topic of a vast scientific debate
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C003, C008, C010 in Pass 2

claims.content: Climate changes during late Pleistocene and early Holocene triggered major migrations of species and biomes in temperate latitudes, with rapid environmental changes like 8200 cal. a BP climatic event and Black Sea flood having major impacts on Neolithic transition
claims.verbatim_quote: It has been argued that rapid environmental changes, such as the 8200 cal. a BP climatic event and Black Sea flood, had major impacts on the Neolithic transition
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C006, C009 in Pass 2

claims.content: General agreement that farming reached Aegean coast somewhat earlier than Balkans' inland valleys and plains
claims.verbatim_quote: there is general agreement that farming reached the Aegean coast somewhat earlier than the Balkans' inland valleys and plains

claims.content: Geographical factors mean Thracian Plain is one of probable corridors through which agriculture made its way into rest of Europe from Western Asia and was home to Europe's earliest metalworking cultures
claims.verbatim_quote: Geographical factors mean that the Thracian Plain is one of the probable corridors through which agriculture made its way into the rest of Europe
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C012, C018 in Pass 2

claims.content: There has been apparent delay in agricultural expansion in Bulgarian Thrace
claims.verbatim_quote: debate about the causes of the apparent delay in agricultural expansion

claims.content: Study presents late-Quaternary pollen, non-pollen palynomorph, magnetic susceptibility and charcoal record from formerly Bulgaria's largest inland water body
claims.verbatim_quote: Here we present a late-Quaternary pollen, non-pollen palynomorph, magnetic susceptibility and charcoal record from a site that was formerly Bulgaria's largest inland water body.

claims.content: Study addresses three research questions about vegetation response to climate change, environmental influence on Neolithic transition, and palaeological registration of human activity
claims.verbatim_quote: Our aim is to address the following questions: 1. How did the vegetation of the Thracian Plain respond to climate changes since the Last Glacial Maximum? 2. Could the environment have influenced the Neolithic transition to agriculture? 3. Is Neolithic and later human activity registered palaeoecologically?

claims.content: Thracian Plain is a fertile basin wedged between mountain chains of Balkans and coastlines of Aegean, Marmara and Black Seas
claims.verbatim_quote: The Thracian Plain is a fertile basin wedged between the mountain chains of the Balkans and the coastlines of the Aegean, Marmara and Black Seas.

claims.content: Throughout its history, the plain has acted as cultural conduit between East and West, criss-crossed by trade routes and rich in archaeological remains
claims.verbatim_quote: Throughout its history, the plain has acted as a cultural conduit between East and West, criss-crossed by trade routes and rich in archaeological remains.

claims.content: Near Eastern crop suite was cultivated on Thracian Plain during Neolithic
claims.verbatim_quote: the full range of Near Eastern crops was cultivated here

claims.content: Surprisingly little is known about environmental context of early agriculture on Thracian Plain
claims.verbatim_quote: In contrast to other parts of Europe, surprisingly little is known about the environmental context of early agriculture on the Thracian Plain.

claims.content: Existing pollen data from Thracian Plain miss early Holocene period
claims.verbatim_quote: The few pollen data that exist from Bulgaria's Thracian Plain miss the early Holocene altogether

claims.content: Previous studies unanimously assert that Thracian Plain was dominated by oak forests prior to clearing associated with agriculture
claims.verbatim_quote: These studies unanimously assert that the Thracian Plain was dominated by oak forests prior to clearing associated with agriculture

claims.content: No previous studies provide direct palynological evidence supporting claim of oak forest dominance on Thracian Plain
claims.verbatim_quote: but none provide direct palynological evidence that would support such a claim

claims.content: Previous terrestrial pollen studies conclude that Thracian Plain's oak forests were destroyed prior to ~4000 cal. a BP, supported by marine sediments from Black Sea showing early-mid Holocene Quercus expansion, though timing of deforestation is unclear from marine records with some showing abrupt Quercus decline around 6000 cal. a BP and others showing no decline at all
claims.verbatim_quote: leading the authors of these studies to conclude that the Thracian Plain's oak forests were destroyed prior to ~4000 cal. a BP
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C024, C025, C026 in Pass 2

claims.content: In marine cores, palaeoecological responses to human impact, climatic changes and sea-level rise can be difficult to disentangle
claims.verbatim_quote: In the marine cores, moreover, palaeoecological responses to human impact, climatic changes and sea-level rise can be difficult to disentangle

claims.content: Straldzha Mire provides appropriate site for examining regional palaeoenvironmental history of Thracian Plain through deep sedimentary sequence suitable for long-term reconstruction, with proximity to previous pollen study site allowing cross-validation of late Holocene results
claims.verbatim_quote: The Straldzha Mire is located in the Karnobat Lowlands at the foot of the Stara Planina Mountains (Fig. 2). These lowlands are part of the pre-Balkan sunkland
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C028, C035, C036 in Pass 2

claims.content: Large size of Straldzha Mire (14,000 ha) makes it significant site for regional-scale palaeovegetation reconstruction
claims.verbatim_quote: making it the largest freshwater wetland basin in Bulgaria

claims.content: Historical botanical records provide baseline understanding of pre-drainage wetland character
claims.verbatim_quote: Early 20th century botanists recorded that the Straldzha Mire was a diverse reed-swamp dominated by Phragmites australis

claims.content: 20th century drainage activities have fundamentally altered wetland ecosystem
claims.verbatim_quote: by the 1960s, the mire was completely drained

claims.content: Pre-agricultural vegetation of Thracian Plain lowlands consisted primarily of oak-dominated forests
claims.verbatim_quote: The area around the mire, like most of Bulgarian Thrace, is thought to have once been vegetated by oak forests

claims.content: Contemporary landscape represents complete transformation from historical forested conditions
claims.verbatim_quote: Today, few remnants of these forest communities remain and the entire lowland is an agricultural landscape.

claims.content: Transitional Mediterranean-continental climate with bimodal precipitation influences regional vegetation patterns
claims.verbatim_quote: The climate of Bulgaria's Thracian Plain is transitional between Mediterranean and continental zones, with two precipitation maxima

claims.content: Variable sampling intervals provide higher resolution for recent sediments while maintaining coverage of entire sequence, with immediate sealing and refrigeration to preserve sample integrity for palynological analysis
claims.verbatim_quote: Samples ~20cm3 in size were taken at 5-cm intervals until a depth of 140 cm from the surface and thereafter at 20-cm intervals.
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C037, C038 in Pass 2

claims.content: Standard pollen preparation techniques with counting thresholds (minimum 200, average 600 pollen grains) and inclusion of non-pollen palynomorphs ensure comparability with other palynological studies and provide statistically robust basis for percentage calculations with complementary environmental indicators beyond pollen evidence
claims.verbatim_quote: Subsamples of 1cm3 were extracted for pollen analysis, combined with Lycopodium spore tablets (University of Lund), treated with 10% HCl, density separation in sodium polytungstate (s.g. 2.0) and acetolysis for 1 minute
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C039, C040, C041 in Pass 2

claims.content: Size-based separation and quantification of microscopic (<200 µm) and macroscopic (>250 µm) charcoal using point-count and Oregon sieving methods with image analysis allows discrimination between local and regional fire signals, with conversion to influx rates accounting for variable sedimentation to provide temporal fire frequency estimates
claims.verbatim_quote: Microscopic charcoal (<200 µm) was quantified on pollen slides using the point-count method
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C042, C043, C044, C045, C046 in Pass 2

claims.content: Mineral magnetic properties reveal changes in sediment source, alteration processes and environmental forcing
claims.verbatim_quote: thus allowing changes in sediment source and alteration to be identified and the driving forces behind magnetic susceptibility changes to be established.

claims.content: Canal core provides more complete representation of upper sedimentary sequence
claims.verbatim_quote: Samples from the westernmost site (canal core, Fig. 2) were taken at 10-cm intervals

claims.content: Detrended Correspondence Analysis and cluster analysis in PC-Ord with taxonomic standardisation to remove methodological artefacts, combined with indicator species analysis (p=0.001 with Monte Carlo testing) and temporal plotting, provides objective statistical basis for comparing palaeovegetational patterns and identifying characteristic taxa across multiple sites while assessing synchronous vs. asynchronous vegetation changes across region
claims.verbatim_quote: Pollen data were analysed numerically to elucidate the palaeoclimatic significance and palaeovegetational context of the results. We used Detrended Correspondence Analysis (DCA: Hill and Gauch, 1980) and minimum variance cluster analysis (Ward, 1963)
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C053, C055, C056, C057, C058, C059, C060 in Pass 2

claims.content: Regional comparison reveals geographical and altitudinal patterns in vegetation development
claims.verbatim_quote: selected a number of representative records from the Bulgarian mountains and the Black Sea area (Fig. 1) in order to compare geographical and altitudinal patterns in vegetation development.

claims.content: Comprehensive radiocarbon dating strategy employed using 13 AMS dates across Straldzha profiles, analysed using Bayesian age-depth modelling to establish chronological framework
claims.verbatim_quote: Thirteen Accelerator Mass Spectrometer radiocarbon dates were obtained for the Straldzha profiles.
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C061, C090 in Pass 2

claims.content: Canal core chronology established through combination of sediment accumulation rates from upper part of record applied to upper metre and statistical correlation with quarry section
claims.verbatim_quote: Sediment accumulation rates in the upper part of the record were also applied to the upper metre of the canal core. The lowermost sample in the core was statistically matched with the beginning of palaeovegetation phase 4 (Section 3.2) and the intervening ages interpolated from the AMS date at 110-cm depth (Fig. 3).
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from E058, C064 in Pass 2

claims.content: Major environmental transition at 125 cm depth marks shift from oxidising terrestrial conditions to lacustrine deposition
claims.verbatim_quote: The most important change in the sedimentary sequence occurred around 125 cm in the quarry section, where the grey to orange-brown sediments laid down under oxidising conditions (Unit III) were overlaid by darker peaty silts and lighter lake marls (Units IV and V).

claims.content: Canal core provides more complete representation of upper sedimentary sequence than quarry section due to variable truncation and disturbance
claims.verbatim_quote: In several fields near the quarry this top layer has been lost completely, exposing the underlying light-grey marl (Unit VI). The canal core is more likely to represent the full sedimentary sequence of this unit.

claims.content: Magnetic susceptibility variations closely track lithological changes across sedimentary sequence
claims.verbatim_quote: Magnetic susceptibility measurements (XLF; Fig. 4) broadly follow lithological changes, exhibiting medium and variable values (0.31–0.15×10-6m3kg-1) in the silty units (I–III), low and stable values (0.11–0.08×10-6m3kg-1) in the marl sediments (IV–VI, and VII in the canal core) and very high values (1.25–0.64×10-6m3kg-1) in the disturbed surface sediments

claims.content: Contrasting magnetic mineralogy between basal silts and marls reflects different depositional environments and sediment sources
claims.verbatim_quote: The basal silt units have much higher amounts of ferrimagnetic material, consisting of both magnetite and maghaemite of likely detrital origin. The marls have very little ferrimagnetic material and are dominated by paramagnetic material, possibly authigenic.

claims.content: Shift from detrital to authigenic magnetic mineral dominance marks transition in sediment sources and formation processes
claims.verbatim_quote: The basal silt units have much higher amounts of ferrimagnetic material, consisting of both magnetite and maghaemite of likely detrital origin. The marls have very little ferrimagnetic material and are dominated by paramagnetic material, possibly authigenic.

claims.content: High magnetic susceptibility in surface sediments directly related to mire drainage and subsequent pedogenesis
claims.verbatim_quote: The disturbed surface sediments are dominated by large amounts of ultra-fine grained magnetite, consistent with ferrimagnetic enhancement via pedogenesis. High magnetic susceptibility is related to the draining of the mire.

claims.content: Pollen preservation affected by multiple factors including sediment chemistry, climate, and recent anthropogenic disturbance
claims.verbatim_quote: Like the core of Tonkov et al. (2008a, 2009), collected nearby, pollen preservation in the sediments was variable. We attribute this to the alkalinity of the sediments, the continental climate and the fact that the wetland was artificially drained some decades ago.

claims.content: Statistical analysis identifies five distinct palaeovegetation phases in Straldzha record with ecologically meaningful indicator taxa
claims.verbatim_quote: Cluster analysis (Fig. 5; supplementary information) was used to group the pollen record into five palaeovegetation phases (Fig. 4), the names of which are based on the assumed ecological preferences of the indicator taxa listed in Table 2. DCA axes 1 and 2 explain 46% and 20% of variance respectively and produced results in strong agreement with the cluster analysis

claims.content: DCA Axis 1 reflects winter temperature and/or rainfall seasonality gradient based on present-day ecology and distribution of represented tree species
claims.verbatim_quote: Axis 1 gives high scores to samples abundant in deciduous tree taxa (especially Quercus) and low scores to samples with abundant coniferous taxa (especially Pinus). Given the present-day ecology and distribution of the tree species represented, this axis perhaps best reflects a winter temperature and/or rainfall seasonality gradient.

claims.content: DCA Axis 2 represents moisture gradient from tree-dominated to xerophytic vegetation
claims.verbatim_quote: Axis 2 gives high scores to samples with abundant tree taxa and low scores to the most important xerophytic taxa, Chenopodiaceae and Artemisia. This axis is thus most easily attributed to a moisture gradient.

claims.content: Cold steppe phase characterized by herb and grass dominance with low but persistent arboreal presence
claims.verbatim_quote: The lowermost zone is dominated by the pollen of herbs and grasses, with an abundance of Artemisia (24–37%) and Poaceae (8–25%). Chenopodiaceae, Ranunculus-type and Polygonum aviculare-type are well represented. Pinus is the most abundant arboreal pollen type (3–26%), but Quercus, Betula, Juniperus and Celtis also occur throughout.

claims.content: Presence of deciduous tree pollen in cold steppe phase indicates refugial populations persisted in region during glacial conditions
claims.verbatim_quote: Pinus is the most abundant arboreal pollen type (3–26%), but Quercus, Betula, Juniperus and Celtis also occur throughout.

claims.content: High Pediastrum abundance indicates substantial aquatic habitat presence during cold steppe phase
claims.verbatim_quote: Pediastrum is abundant (up to 12 times the terrestrial pollen sum).

claims.content: Semidesert phase represents major environmental shift to extreme aridity with Chenopodiaceae-dominated vegetation
claims.verbatim_quote: At the beginning of the second zone, Artemisia and arboreal pollen decline and Chenopodiaceae rises to a peak, completely dominating the pollen assemblage (58–69%).

claims.content: Late semidesert phase marks beginning of Holocene afforestation process with resurgence of deciduous trees
claims.verbatim_quote: Toward the end of the zone, arboreal pollen begins a resurgence led by Quercus, Corylus and Ulmus.

claims.content: Pistacia terebinthus shrubs took part in early Holocene vegetation of Thracian Plain based on constant low pollen percentages
claims.verbatim_quote: Pistacia's poor pollen productivity (Roberts, 2002) implies that P. terebinthus shrubs took part in the early Holocene vegetation of the Thracian Plain, which also included a mixture of deciduous oaks, rosaceous shrubs and grassy meadow communities.

claims.content: Grazing and fire were perhaps not main factors stalling expansion of oak during forest-steppe phase based on reduced charcoal and dung fungi
claims.verbatim_quote: Importantly, charcoal concentrations and the occurrence of dung-inhabiting fungi are reduced during the forest-steppe phase, so grazing and fire were perhaps not the main factors stalling the expansion of oak.

claims.content: Oak woods phase beginning ~8900 cal. a BP marked by Quercus becoming dominant arboreal taxon (30-52% of total pollen sum), transitioning from forest-steppe as thermophilous deciduous trees expanded and grassland indicators declined
claims.verbatim_quote: Around 8700 cal. a BP, Quercus commenced a rapid expansion and meadow vegetation contracted, creating a forest landscape that persisted until ~4000 cal. a BP.
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C080, C083 in Pass 2

claims.content: Oak woods phase characterized by reduced disturbance indicators (charcoal, grassland taxa, dung fungal spores)
claims.verbatim_quote: Charcoal, Chenopodiaceae, grassland taxa and dung fungal spores are reduced.

claims.content: Straldzha Mire existed as carbonate-rich lake during oak woods phase based on aquatic indicators
claims.verbatim_quote: Around Straldzha Mire, which at the time was a carbonate-rich lake with predominantly authigenic sedimentation, oak forest expansion stalled for 2500–3000 years after its initial Holocene advance (Fig. 5).

claims.content: Deforestation phase beginning ~4000 cal. a BP marked by sharp forest decline and increased human impact indicators
claims.verbatim_quote: A phase of deforestation represents the final stage in the vegetation history of Bulgaria's Thracian Plain and is more faithfully registered in the canal core than in the quarry section.

claims.content: Late succession of Fagus and Carpinus preceded deforestation based on canal core evidence
claims.verbatim_quote: The canal core, which is regarded as a more complete representation of this phase, indicates that deforestation was preceded by the late succession of Fagus and Carpinus and followed by considerable peaks in Salix, Alnus and fern spores, and a temporary recovery of Quercus.

claims.content: Pioneer species (Salix, Alnus, ferns) temporarily colonized cleared areas following deforestation with brief Quercus recovery
claims.verbatim_quote: The canal core, which is regarded as a more complete representation of this phase, indicates that deforestation was preceded by the late succession of Fagus and Carpinus and followed by considerable peaks in Salix, Alnus and fern spores, and a temporary recovery of Quercus.

claims.content: Final stage of deforestation phase characterized by cereal cultivation and increased fire activity
claims.verbatim_quote: All of these taxa decrease toward the end of the zone, when Chenopodiaceae, Triticum-type and macroscopic charcoal increase.

claims.content: Low organic content and large error margins led to exclusion of three radiocarbon dates (particularly problematic sample Wk-32001) from age-depth model, improving agreement index from 12% to acceptable level (Amodel 60%)
claims.verbatim_quote: Three dated points were initially excluded from the age-depth model, having both low organic content and large error margins.
claims.rationalization_note: Consolidated from C091, C093, C094 in Pass 2

claims.content: Pollen concentrate radiocarbon ages may be affected by residual carbonates adhering to pollen grain walls
claims.verbatim_quote: Residual carbonates adhering to the pollen grain walls may explain the discrepancy between 14C ages for pollen concentrates and bulk sediment samples (Kilian et al., 2002).

claims.content: Pleistocene-Holocene transition at Straldzha occurred around 128-130 cm depth, corresponding to lithological and vegetation changes
claims.verbatim_quote: This model (Fig. 3) places the Pleistocene–Holocene boundary around 128–130 cm, close to the lithological change and initial oak pollen increase at 125 cm.

claims.content: Straldzha pollen record represents regional vegetation changes over large spatial area (~10^4-10^5 km^2) rather than local changes
claims.verbatim_quote: Only large-scale vegetation changes are thus expected to register in the Straldzha pollen record.

claims.content: Considerable uncertainty attached to pre-Holocene chronology due to low organic content, possible old carbon effects and overlapping ages
claims.verbatim_quote: Considerable uncertainty is attached to the pre-Holocene section, which is affected by low organic content, possible old carbon effects and overlapping ages for different sediment depths.

claims.content: Cold steppe vegetation at Straldzha corresponds to MIS 2 and 3 conditions documented across wider Balkan and Black Sea region
claims.verbatim_quote: This phase corresponds to pollen spectra dated to Marine Isotope Stages (MIS) 2 and 3 in the Tenaghi Philippon record (Müller et al., 2011) and also occurs in pollen records from the Black Sea (Atanassova, 2005; Shumilovskikh et al., 2012) and the mountains of SW Bulgaria (Fig. 5).

claims.content: Cold steppe vegetation at Straldzha interpreted as dry steppe and wooded steppe landscape similar to Ezero
claims.verbatim_quote: Similar pollen assemblages appear in the earliest part of the Ezero record (Magyari et al., 2008), dated around 15,000 cal. a BP, and were interpreted as a landscape of dry steppe and wooded steppe.

claims.content: Arboreal taxa present on Thracian Plain during glacial period but hardly evident in pollen data due to reduced pollen production under cold conditions
claims.verbatim_quote: Plant macrofossil data from Ezero indicate that arboreal taxa such as Juniperus, Celtis, Quercus, Betula and certain Rosaceae were present on the Thracian Plain, but their presence is hardly evident from pollen data perhaps because of reduced pollen production under glacial conditions (Magyari et al., 2008; Feurdean et al., 2012; see also Willis, 1994).

claims.content: Patches of xeric woodland probably present around Straldzha Mire during cold steppe phase as part of refugial populations
claims.verbatim_quote: Similar patches of xeric woodland were probably present around the Straldzha Mire, since the same pollen taxa occur during the cold steppe phase and the eastern Balkans is regarded as one of the probable refugial areas for deciduous thermophilous trees (Krebs et al., 2004; Leroy and Arpe, 2007; Bozilova et al., 2011).

claims.content: Climate during cold steppe phase was considerably colder than present based on presence of Betula
claims.verbatim_quote: The presence of Betula, however, seems to indicate a climate considerably colder than at present (Tarasov et al., 1998; Magyari et al., 2008).

claims.content: Cold steppe phase characterized by colder but variable climatic conditions during MIS 3 and into MIS 2
claims.verbatim_quote: The magnetic susceptibility and mineralogy of this period suggests that detrital input into the lake alternated with derived, pedogenically enhanced sediments, and this potentially reflects colder but variable climatic conditions consistent with deposition during MIS 3 and into MIS 2.

claims.content: Pine trees present in region throughout last glacial period but Pinus pollen largely derived from distant sources
claims.verbatim_quote: Pine trees were also present in the region throughout the last glacial period. Pinus pollen concentrations did not vary substantially from the Pleistocene to the Holocene (supplementary information), suggesting that much of the Pinus pollen in Straldzha Mire was blown in from distant sources.

claims.content: Arboreal pollen minimum around 35,000 cal. a BP represents coldest/driest conditions during cold steppe phase
claims.verbatim_quote: The lowest arboreal pollen contribution (7.5%) is recorded at the earliest part of the cold steppe phase, corresponding to the grey silt band around 35,000 cal. a BP.

claims.content: Mid-MIS 3 arboreal pollen minimum at Straldzha correlates with similar minima across Balkans, possibly reflecting regional climatic fluctuation
claims.verbatim_quote: Similar minima, dated to ~39,000 cal. a BP (mid MIS 3), are recorded at Lake Prespa (Leng et al., in press) and Tenaghi Philippon (Müller et al., 2011), possibly reflecting a regional climatic fluctuation.

claims.content: Higher arboreal percentages (up to 35%) in later part of cold steppe phase likely reflect expansion of frost-tolerant woodland during MIS 2
claims.verbatim_quote: Higher arboreal percentages (up to 35%), especially of Pinus, in the later part of the phase are most likely to reflect the expansion of frost-tolerant woodland during MIS 2 (Müller et al., 2011).

research_designs.content: Multi-proxy palaeoenvironmental approach combining pollen, non-pollen palynomorphs, magnetic susceptibility, and charcoal to provide comprehensive environmental reconstruction
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Here we present a late-Quaternary pollen, non-pollen palynomorph, magnetic susceptibility and charcoal record from a site that was formerly Bulgaria's largest inland water body.

research_designs.content: Three research questions framework addressing vegetation-climate response, environmental influence on Neolithic transition, and palaeological registration of human activity
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Our aim is to address the following questions: 1. How did the vegetation of the Thracian Plain respond to climate changes since the Last Glacial Maximum? 2. Could the environment have influenced the Neolithic transition to agriculture? 3. Is Neolithic and later human activity registered palaeoecologically?

research_designs.content: Selection of Straldzha Mire as study site based on formerly Bulgaria's largest inland water body providing regional palaeoenvironmental signal
research_designs.verbatim_quote: from a site that was formerly Bulgaria's largest inland water body

research_designs.content: Temporal scope from Last Glacial Maximum to present to capture long-term vegetation response and agricultural transition
research_designs.verbatim_quote: environmental change in this region since the Last Glacial Maximum

research_designs.content: Dual-core sampling strategy using quarry section for deep time and canal core for undisturbed late Holocene sequence
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Since the upper part of the Straldzha quarry record may have been disturbed or truncated by quarrying activities, we obtained additional cores from three locations on the mire

research_designs.content: Regional synthesis approach using DCA and cluster analysis to compare Straldzha record with existing Bulgarian pollen sites across altitudinal and geographical gradients
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We used Detrended Correspondence Analysis (DCA: Hill and Gauch, 1980) and minimum variance cluster analysis (Ward, 1963) to compare pre-existing pollen data to the new record.

research_designs.content: Standardisation of pollen taxonomy across sites to enable cross-site comparison despite methodological differences
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Pollen taxonomy was standardised to a base of 99 taxa (see supplementary information), resulting in some loss of information. This standardisation was necessary to remove the influence of different pollen-taxonomic systems

research_designs.content: Multi-proxy integration strategy for combining pollen, charcoal, magnetic susceptibility, and NPP data to reconstruct palaeoenvironmental history
research_designs.trigger_text: pollen, non-pollen palynomorph, magnetic susceptibility and charcoal record
research_designs.inference_reasoning: Paper presents integrated interpretation of four proxy types, but provides no documented framework for how these proxies are synthesised, weighted, or reconciled when they provide contradictory signals. The integration strategy is operationally necessary but undocumented.

research_designs.content: Reference site selection strategy for regional comparative analysis using European Pollen Database
research_designs.trigger_text: selected a number of representative records from the Bulgarian mountains and the Black Sea area
research_designs.inference_reasoning: Sites selected for comparison (Fig. 1, Fig. 5) but criteria for 'representative' not documented. Geographic proximity? Temporal coverage? Methodological comparability? Site selection fundamentally shapes regional synthesis but rationale unstated.

methods.content: Pollen analysis using Lycopodium marker technique for concentration calculation
methods.verbatim_quote: Subsamples of 1cm3 were extracted for pollen analysis, combined with Lycopodium spore tablets (University of Lund)

methods.content: Standard pollen preparation using HCl treatment, density separation, and acetolysis
methods.verbatim_quote: treated with 10% HCl, density separation in sodium polytungstate (s.g. 2.0) and acetolysis for 1 minute

methods.content: Pollen identification and counting using light microscopy at 400× magnification
methods.verbatim_quote: prior to being mounted in glycerol and identified at 400× magnification. At least 200 (average 600) terrestrial pollen were counted in each sample.

methods.content: Non-pollen palynomorph (NPP) analysis for additional environmental indicators
methods.verbatim_quote: Non-pollen palynomorphs were classified according to Jankovská and Komárek (2000), van Geel (2001) and van Geel and Aptroot (2006).

methods.content: Microscopic charcoal quantification using point-count method on pollen slides
methods.verbatim_quote: Microscopic charcoal (<200 µm) was quantified on pollen slides using the point-count method (Clark, 1982)

methods.content: Macroscopic charcoal quantification using modified Oregon sieving method
methods.verbatim_quote: macroscopic charcoal (>250 µm) was quantified using a modification of the 'Oregon sieving method' (Long et al., 1998; Mooney and Tinner, 2011).

methods.content: Charcoal concentration to influx conversion by normalising for deposition time
methods.verbatim_quote: Charcoal concentrations were then converted to an influx (also known as charcoal accumulation rates or CHAR), by normalising for the deposition time of the sample.

methods.content: Dual-frequency magnetic susceptibility measurements for sediment characterisation
methods.verbatim_quote: Dual-frequency magnetic susceptibility measurements were run on a Bartington MS2 magnetic susceptibility meter following the protocols outlined by Dearing (1999) and Herries and Fisher (2010).

methods.content: Mineral magnetic analysis using Variable Field Translation Balance (VFTB) for detailed magnetic mineralogy characterisation
methods.verbatim_quote: Additional mineral magnetic analysis was undertaken on a Magnetic Measurements Variable Field Translation Balance (VFTB), including isothermal remanent magnetisation (IRM) acquisition curves and backfields, hysteresis loops and thermomagnetic curves.

methods.content: Pollen diagram visualization using Psimpoll software with graphic design choices for exaggeration factors, color schemes, grouping, and axis scaling
methods.consolidation_note: Pass 5: Consolidated M025 (implicit visualization methodology) into explicit Psimpoll method

methods.content: Numerical pollen data analysis to elucidate palaeoclimatic significance and palaeovegetational context
methods.verbatim_quote: Pollen data were analysed numerically to elucidate the palaeoclimatic significance and palaeovegetational context of the results.

methods.content: Detrended Correspondence Analysis (DCA) for palaeovegetation pattern analysis
methods.verbatim_quote: We used Detrended Correspondence Analysis (DCA: Hill and Gauch, 1980) and minimum variance cluster analysis (Ward, 1963) to compare pre-existing pollen data to the new record.

methods.content: Minimum variance cluster analysis for grouping pollen records and defining vegetation associations
methods.verbatim_quote: minimum variance cluster analysis (Ward, 1963) to compare pre-existing pollen data to the new record.

methods.content: Indicator species analysis combined with clustering to determine optimal vegetation groupings
methods.verbatim_quote: A combination of minimum variance clustering and indicator species analysis (Dufrêne and Legendre, 1997) was used to determine an optimum number of groups.

methods.content: Radiocarbon dating using Accelerator Mass Spectrometer (AMS) on multiple sample types including pollen concentrates, organic residues, and macrobotanical material
methods.verbatim_quote: Thirteen Accelerator Mass Spectrometer radiocarbon dates were obtained for the Straldzha profiles.
methods.consolidation_note: Pass 5: Consolidated M016 (pollen concentrate dating) as specific application of AMS dating method

methods.content: Bayesian age-depth modelling using Markov chain Monte-Carlo analysis in OxCal, extended by linear extrapolation to cover intervals beyond dated samples
methods.verbatim_quote: An age-depth model was constructed for the quarry section using Markov chain Monte-Carlo analysis, a Bayesian statistical approach to age modelling implemented in OxCal 4.1.7 (Bronk Ramsey, 2009), based on the IntCal09 calibration curve (Reimer et al., 2009).
methods.consolidation_note: Pass 5: Consolidated M018 (linear extrapolation) as procedural extension of age-depth modelling

methods.content: Statistical correlation of canal core chronology with quarry section using palaeovegetation phase boundaries
methods.verbatim_quote: The lowermost sample in the core was statistically matched with the beginning of palaeovegetation phase 4 (Section 3.2) and the intervening ages interpolated from the AMS date at 110-cm depth

methods.content: European Pollen Database integration for regional palaeovegetational comparison
methods.verbatim_quote: We made use of data publicly available through the European Pollen Database (Fyfe et al., 2009) and selected a number of representative records from the Bulgarian mountains and the Black Sea area

methods.content: Pollen preservation assessment method
methods.trigger_text: pollen preservation in the sediments was variable
methods.inference_reasoning: Variable preservation documented and attributed to alkalinity, climate, and drainage, but method for assessing preservation quality not specified. Preservation assessment likely affected counting procedures and interpretation but methodology not documented.

methods.content: Age-depth model quality evaluation criteria and decision rules for excluding dates
methods.trigger_text: performance statistics indicated poor agreement; Exclusion of Wk-32001 increased the model's agreement index to a more acceptable level
methods.inference_reasoning: Agreement index thresholds (12% = poor, 58% = acceptable) used to evaluate and modify age-depth model, but criteria for acceptable agreement not documented. Decision rules for iterative date exclusion process not specified.

methods.content: Regional pollen source area estimation method
methods.trigger_text: representative of a large spatial area, estimated at ~10^4-10^5 km^2
methods.inference_reasoning: Source area estimate cited from Sugita (2007) but application method not documented. How basin size (14,000 ha) translated to source area estimate? Site-specific calculations or general assumption? Critical for interpreting spatial scale of vegetation changes.

methods.content: Palaeovegetation phase boundary determination from cluster analysis
methods.trigger_text: Cluster analysis was used to group the pollen record into five palaeovegetation phases
methods.inference_reasoning: Cluster analysis produced five phases but criteria for selecting five (vs 4 or 6) not documented. Phase boundary placement involves subjective decisions about optimal cluster number that are assessment-critical but undocumented.

protocols.content: Quarry trench excavation: 520 cm deep × 30 cm wide into quarry side at 42°37'49"N, 26°46'12"E, 138 m a.s.l.
protocols.verbatim_quote: In March 2008, we dug a trench 520 cm deep and 30 cm wide into the side of the "Straldja" tile factory's quarry in the lowest part of the Straldzha Mire (Fig. 2; 42º37'49"N, 26º46'12"E, 138 m a.s.l.).

protocols.content: Variable resolution sampling strategy: 5-cm intervals to 140 cm depth (higher resolution for recent sediments), then 20-cm intervals to bottom (maintaining coverage while balancing temporal resolution and practical constraints)
protocols.verbatim_quote: Samples ~20cm3 in size were taken at 5-cm intervals until a depth of 140 cm from the surface and thereafter at 20-cm intervals.
protocols.consolidation_note: Pass 5: Consolidated P046 (implicit sampling interval rationale) into explicit variable sampling protocol

protocols.content: Immediate sealing of samples in plastic bags and refrigerated storage for preservation
protocols.verbatim_quote: The samples were immediately sealed in plastic bags and stored in a refrigerator.

protocols.content: Pollen subsample extraction: 1 cm³ subsamples combined with Lycopodium spore tablets (University of Lund) at specified concentration and addition volume for concentration calculation
protocols.verbatim_quote: Subsamples of 1cm3 were extracted for pollen analysis, combined with Lycopodium spore tablets (University of Lund)
protocols.consolidation_note: Pass 5: Consolidated P036 (implicit Lycopodium tablet concentration/volume specifications) into explicit Lycopodium addition protocol

protocols.content: Pollen preparation sequence: 10% HCl treatment, density separation in sodium polytungstate (s.g. 2.0), acetolysis for 1 minute
protocols.verbatim_quote: treated with 10% HCl, density separation in sodium polytungstate (s.g. 2.0) and acetolysis for 1 minute

protocols.content: Pollen mounting in glycerol for microscopic examination
protocols.verbatim_quote: prior to being mounted in glycerol and identified at 400× magnification

protocols.content: Pollen counting thresholds and stopping rules: minimum 200, average 600 terrestrial pollen per sample, with decision rules for when to stop at minimum vs. continue to average count based on assemblage diversity
protocols.verbatim_quote: At least 200 (average 600) terrestrial pollen were counted in each sample.
protocols.consolidation_note: Pass 5: Consolidated P035 (implicit stopping rules) into explicit counting threshold protocol

protocols.content: Pollen identification using Moore et al. (1991) and Reille (1999) reference atlases
protocols.verbatim_quote: Pollen identifications were made with reference to Moore et al. (1991) and Reille (1999).

protocols.content: NPP classification using Jankovská and Komárek (2000), van Geel (2001), and van Geel and Aptroot (2006) schemes
protocols.verbatim_quote: Non-pollen palynomorphs were classified according to Jankovská and Komárek (2000), van Geel (2001) and van Geel and Aptroot (2006).

protocols.content: Microscopic charcoal point-count method following Clark (1982) on pollen slides
protocols.verbatim_quote: Microscopic charcoal (<200 µm) was quantified on pollen slides using the point-count method (Clark, 1982)

protocols.content: Macroscopic charcoal processing: ~2 cm³ sediment in 4.2% sodium hypochlorite for 24 hours, wash through 250 µm sieve, hand-sort, photograph
protocols.verbatim_quote: A known volume (~2 cm3) of sediment was placed in dilute (4.2%) sodium hypochlorite (bleach) for 24 hours (Rhodes 1998) and then washed through a 250 µm sieve. The captured material was hand-sorted to remove extraneous material and the charcoal photographed using a high-resolution digital camera.

protocols.content: Charcoal concentration quantification using Scion Image 4.0.3.2 image analysis software, expressed as mm² per cm³
protocols.verbatim_quote: Charcoal concentrations were quantified using image analysis software (Scion Image 4.0.3.2). This resulted in the concentration of macroscopic charcoal >250 µm, expressed as an area (mm2 per cm3).

protocols.content: Charcoal influx (CHAR) calculation by normalising concentration for sample deposition time
protocols.verbatim_quote: Charcoal concentrations were then converted to an influx (also known as charcoal accumulation rates or CHAR), by normalising for the deposition time of the sample.
